thread.title: Malcolm Turnbull will take Australia to 'the next level' with China, says James Packer
thread.title_full: Malcolm Turnbull will take Australia to 'the next level' with China, says James Packer

author: Chris Jenkins, Perry Williams
title: Malcolm Turnbull will take Australia to 'the next level' with China, says James Packer
text:
"I've known Malcolm Turnbull for a very long time and I share his optimism about Australia's future and the opportunities that exist here if we get our policies right,"says James Packer. Photo: Pat Scala
Malcolm Turnbull touted as a more likely tax reformer than Tony Abbott The business of being Lucy Turnbull
Turnbull a 'shot in the arm' for Australia
Gaming billionaire James Packer says Australia will forever be in Tony Abbott's debt for forging free trade agreements with China, South Korea and Japan.
Malcolm understands China and its importance to our economic security and the quality of life of Australian families.
James Packer But new Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull was the leader to take Australia's pivotal relationship with China to "the next level", Melco Crown Entertainment chair Mr Packer said.
The business sector has generally welcomed the arrival of Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull. Photo: Alex Ellinghausen
Welcoming Mr Turnbull and deputy Julie Bishop as a "formidable team", Mr Packer acknowledged Mr Abbott and Trade Minister Andrew Robb played key roles in forging the trade agreements with major regional players.
Advertisement "Tony Abbott did a fantastic job leading and finalising the free trade agreements with South Korea, Japan and now China and the country is forever indebted to him and Andrew Robb for that.
"It will be Tony's economic legacy," Mr Packer said.
Malcolm Turnbull with Kerry Packer in 1984.
But it would be the Liberals' new leadership that would capitalise on the agreements, he said.
"I've known Malcolm Turnbull for a very long time and I share his optimism about Australia's future and the opportunities that exist here if we get our policies right," Mr Packer told Fairfax Media.
"Malcolm understands China and its importance to our economic security and the quality of life of Australian families. Malcolm and Julie Bishop will be a formidable team on the world stage and are probably the most qualified politicians in the Parliament to build on this work and take the Australia China relationship to the next level."
Welcome wagon Mr Packer joined a chorus of business, investment and economic figures heralding the arrival of Mr Turnbull in the nation's top job. With a pledge to put economics at the centre of his leadership, Mr Turnbull could help restore the confidence of Australia's businesses and consumers, many commentators said on Tuesday.
"Reform is daunting for politicians but I think they've got the right idea. What they've been missing is the rhetoric so they can sell these ideas to the Australian people," former BHP chairman and NAB chief Don Argus said .
Investa Office Fund chairman Deborah Page said Mr Turnbull brought the right personal qualities to the job. "Malcolm Turnbull brings an intellect and business acumen to the role second to none. Unlike his predecessor, he will bring curiosity and openness to the future combined with a strong grasp of the digital revolution and its opportunities," she said.
Royal Bank of Canada's head of economics for Australia Su-lin Ong said the country had lacked economic leadership.
"We are mindful that the global economy has faced numerous challenges during this period, but we have long argued that confidence is structurally weaker due to the lack of strong national leadership, little focus on much-needed reform to boost long-run growth, and the lack of a clear economic narrative," she said.
"A key weakness on both sides of politics has been the Treasurer," she said.
On Tuesday incumbent Treasurer Joe Hockey defended the government's economic record but many political observers believe he will be forced to make way for Scott Morrison when Mr Turnbull reshapes the ministry.
Towards the centre Perennial Value fund manager John Murray said Mr Turnbull's centrist political approach would benefit the country. "I don't think Australia is suited to hard-line policies, either left or right, and in itself a move towards the centre should be better for Australia."
Wilson Asset Management chairman Geoff Wilson said leadership and confidence were required in the face of an uncertain global economic climate.
"Unemployment is up, there are a number of economic headwinds, whether it's globally, China slowing down, obviously the mining slowdown. To me you need confidence," he said.
"When we invest in a company we're looking for companies that are extremely well managed and if I'm looking at investing in Australia I want it to be incredibly well managed and I believe Malcolm Turnbull can do that."
Fears about global economic conditions are growing, with a slowdown in China's rate of growth a key concern.
Mr Turnbull's former employer, investment bank Goldman Sachs, predicting last week that there was a one-in-three-chance that Australia would slip into a recession .
